unnormalised: **Rental Agreements: Your Guide to Not Getting Royally Screwed (Like Raju did!)**
normalised: Okay, so you're moving to Mumbai (or Bangalore, Chennai...wherever your I T dreams take you!). First thing you'll need? A place to live. And that means a rental agreement. Don't be like my friend Raju. He just shook hands with the landlord, paid his deposit (rupees fifty thousand!), and thought everything was sorted. Spoiler alert: it wasn't.

unnormalised: Okay, so you're moving to Mumbai (or Bangalore, Chennai...wherever your IT dreams take you!). First thing you'll need? A place to live. And that means a rental agreement. Don't be like my friend Raju. He just shook hands with the landlord, paid his deposit (Rs. 50,000!), and thought everything was sorted. Spoiler alert: it wasn't.
normalised: He ended up having a *major* disagreement about late payment charges (rupees five hundred per day!) and who was responsible for fixing the leaky tap in the bathroom. A properly drafted rental agreement could have saved him a lot of headaches (and money!).

unnormalised: He ended up having a *major* disagreement about late payment charges (Rs. 500 per day!) and who was responsible for fixing the leaky tap in the bathroom. A properly drafted rental agreement could have saved him a lot of headaches (and money!).
normalised: Think of it like this: it's like ordering biryani. You want to know *exactly* what you're getting - mutton or chicken, how spicy it is, the quantity, right? Same with your rental. The agreement should clearly state the rent amount (rupees fifteen thousand per month, say), the duration of the lease (eleven months is common), the deposit amount, late payment penalties, maintenance responsibilities (the dreaded plumbing!), and notice period for moving out.

unnormalised: Think of it like this: it's like ordering biryani. You want to know *exactly* what you're getting - mutton or chicken, how spicy it is, the quantity, right? Same with your rental. The agreement should clearly state the rent amount (Rs. 15,000/month, say), the duration of the lease (11 months is common), the deposit amount, late payment penalties, maintenance responsibilities (the dreaded plumbing!), and notice period for moving out.
normalised: Also, make sure it specifies if pets are allowed, any restrictions on guests (especially during Onam!), and whether you can make alterations to the property. Get it notarized too! It makes things extra legit.

normalised: Pro-tip: Negotiate! Landlords often inflate costs a little. Don't be shy to haggle (politely, of course!). It’s all part of the game. Good luck with your flat hunting!
